questions.text: Most common rheumatic disease in children is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common rheumatic disease in children is juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis represents a heterogeneous group of chronic disorders characterized by

  • Arthritis* in ≥1 joint 
  • Age at onset: <16 years
  • Duration of disease: ≥6 weeks

*Arthritis clinically defined as swelling or effusion, or the presence of 2 or more of the following signs:

  • limitation of range of motion
  • tenderness or pain on motion
  • increased heat

questions.text: You are evaluating JIA patients in a pediatric rheumatology clinic. As per the ILAR criteria, which of the following patients would you not include under JIA?

choices.text: A 18-year-old with RF negative Polyarthritis first diagnosed 3 years back

questions.solution:
Reactive arthritis is not a subtype of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis(JIA) so you would not include this subset of patients under your evaluation.

ILAR (International League of Associations for Rheumatology) defines JIA as arthritis of one or more joints with onset below 16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks.

The subtypes of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):-

  1. Oligoarthritis (4 or lesser joints) (Most common type)
  2. Polyarthritis (5 or more joints)
    1. RF Positive
    2. RF Negative
  3. Systemic JIA
  4. Psoriatic arthritis
  5. Enthesitis-related arthritis
  6. Undifferentiated

questions.text: Mohit is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of red-eye. He complains of blurring of vision and on examination, the pupil appears as shown in the picture. Which of the following subtype of JIA is associated with the highest risk for the ophthalmic complication noted in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has red-eye and the blurring of vision along with the finding of the irregular pupil, which is suggestive of uveitis. ANA-positive oligoarthritis is associated with the highest risk for uveitis in patients with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.

The presence of a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) confers increased risk for uveitis in children with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination every 3 months.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 4-year-old girl who has been complaining about pain in the joints of arms and legs for 2 months. On examination, multiple nodules over the bony prominences suggestive of rheumatoid nodules are noted. On investigation, RA-factor was found positive pointing to the diagnosis of RF-positive polyarthritis. Which of the following complication is not likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ankylosis is not seen in patients with RF-positive Polyarthritis.

Polyarthritis is characterized by inflammation of ≥5 joints in both upper and lower extremities. Rheumatoid factor (RF)–positive polyarthritis resembles the characteristic symmetric presentation of adult rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid nodules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, spine, and over the Achilles tendons are associated with a more severe course and almost exclusively occur in RF-positive individuals.

Complications may include:

  • Micrognathia (due to chronic temporomandibular joint disease)
  • Cervical spine involvement, manifesting as decreased neck extension, occurs with a risk of atlantoaxial subluxation and neurologic sequelae.
  • Hip disease may be subtle, with findings of erosion.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) factor is negative in systemic JIA. It is positive in a subtype of polyarthritic type of JIA.

Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + at least one of 

  • Evanescent erythematous rash
  • Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • Serositis

questions.text: Anuj, a school-going kid has been brought to the pediatric OPD by his mother with complaints of fever for 3 weeks. She says her son has been skipping school because of the fever but in the evening he gets better and plays with his siblings. She also noticed a rash that appears along with fever and disappears spontaneously. He has a history of joint pain on and off since pre-school. On examination, generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are noted along with an evanescent erythematous rash on the trunk. Which of the following characteristically defines the fever associated with this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has clinical features of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA), which is associated with quotidian fever. Quotidian fever - fever that rises to 39°C (102.2°F) once a day and returns to 37°C (98.6°F) between fever peaks

Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + at least one of 

  1. Evanescent erythematous rash that is non-pruritic and migratory with lesions lasting<1 hr.
  2. Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly
  3. Generalized lymphadenopathy
  4. Serositis

questions.text: Aarav is a known case of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). He is referred to a Rheumatology specialist center from a local hospital, when his condition started deteriorating on steroid treatment. On examination, the patient has lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and purpura along with the acute onset of high spiking fevers. Vitals show persistent hypotension (85/45 mmHg), tachycardia (160/min), and oliguria. He was urgently admitted into the PICU. The resident physician is confused between macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) and JIA flare-up. Which of the following is best suited to distinguish these two?
questions.solution:
Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) is characterized by all of the listed features. However, the diagnosis is confirmed by bone marrow biopsy demonstrating hemophagocytosis and is the best test to distinguish MAS from a flare-up of JIA.

MAS is a rare but potentially fatal complication of systemic JIA. It is characterized by an uncontrolled activation and proliferation of T lymphocytes and macrophages. It is the result of a cytokine storm that leads to a dysregulated inflammatory activation of the immune system, with rapid progression to multiorgan failure if not promptly diagnosed and properly treated. It is characterized by the following:

  • Macrophage hemophagocytosis in the bone marrow
  • Hypofibrinogenemia  (paradoxical fall in erythrocyte sedimentation rate [ESR])
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Extreme hyperferritinemia
  • Fever >38.5°C
  • Splenomegaly
  • Cytopenia affecting at least two of three cell lineages

Treatment usually includes high-dose corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents in refractory cases. 

 

MAS can occur in many diseases like SLE, JIA, Kawasaki disease, sepsis, dengue and also Covid19.

questions.text: A mother brought her 12-day old baby to the OPD due to the rash shown in the picture for the last 5 days. The mother says the rash gets worse in the sun. The infant was born at home and she never had a prenatal check-up. She herself has a history of joint pains and a facial rash which she says is "no big deal". On examination, Vitals are normal for the baby. A subsequent ECG shows P wave rate 120/min and R wave rate at 70/min with no relation between the two. Which of the following antibodies will be used to diagnose this baby's condition?
questions.solution:
The baby has raccoon eyes (periorbital rash) with complete heart block (P-R dissociation) suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE). Anti-Ro antibodies are used to diagnose neonatal lupus. 

Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus(NLE):

NLE is not an autoimmune condition. It occurs when maternal autoantibodies enter the fetal circulation (passive transfer). The antibodies responsible for this condition are anti-Ro antibody (anti-SSA) and anti-La antibody (anti-SSB).

The periorbital rash typically appears within 6 weeks of life and lasts 3-4 months. However, it can be present at birth. Infants may also have cytopenias and hepatitis, but the most feared complication is congenital heart block. Cardiomyopathy is seen in the most severe cases. The noncardiac manifestations of neonatal lupus are usually reversible, whereas congenital heart block is permanent. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age.

Fluorinated corticosteroids seem to improve cases of hydrops. Significant conduction system abnormalities after birth are treated with cardiac pacing and occasionally intravenous immunoglobulin and steroids, while severe cardiomyopathy may require cardiac transplantation. Transient, noncardiac manifestations are conservatively managed, with topical steroids used occasionally to treat the rash. 

Other options:

Anti-Jo antibodies are a type of myositis-specific antibodies. These are not related to neonatal lupus. 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for SLE (Systemic Lupus erythematosus).

Anti-histone antibodies are present in Drug-induced SLE.

Note:

SS in SSA and SSB stands for Sjögren's syndrome-related. Anti-SSA and anti SSB are antinuclear antibodies and are mainly found in patients with SLE and Sjögren's syndrome.

questions.text: Vikas, a high school student is observed to have an indented 'en coup de sabre' lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
En coup de sabre lesion is seen in juvenile localized scleroderma (morphea).

It appears as an indented, vertical, colourless, line of skin on the forehead. The indentation looks as though the person may have been struck (coup) by a sword (sabre). This lesion involves the scalp and/or face and often extend into the central nervous system, resulting in neurologic sequelae such as seizures and headaches.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in the lower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in a child is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases.

The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the affected blood vessels. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.

Clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, the hallmark feature of HSP, which characteristically involves the extensor surfaces of arms and legs. Musculoskeletal symptoms such as arthritis and arthralgia are common. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Renal involvement may lead to gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases. Nephritis usually follows the appearance of the rash. 

Diagnosis of HSP is primarily based on clinical findings, including the palpable purpura, along with the presence of other symptoms. Laboratory tests are not specific to HSP but may show nonspecific markers of inflammation and sometimes elevated levels of IgA. Imaging studies and biopsies of affected tissues can provide additional diagnostic information

Treatment of HSP is generally supportive, focusing on hydration, pain relief, and nutrition. Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases or for significant gastrointestinal involvement. Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and plasma exchange are occasionally employed for severe disease. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine. Complications of HSP can include serious gastrointestinal problems, kidney disease, and recurrences, but overall, the prognosis for childhood HSP is favorable. Regular monitoring of blood pressure and urine is recommended to detect and manage potential complications.

questions.text: Pinky, a small child with Kawasaki disease is admitted to the ward for treatment. Which of the following feature would you not expect to see in her?
questions.solution:
Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease. Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival infection with limbal sparing is characteristically seen in Kawasaki disease.

Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome and is commonly seen in children between 3 months to 5 years of age.

Note: Perineal desquamation is common in the acute phase, while the periungual desquamation begins 2-3 weeks after the onset of illness and may even progress to involve the entire hand and foot.

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: A worried father brought her 5-year-old son to the pediatrician with a history of fever, rash, irritability, and poor feeding. A few days back, he developed perianal desquamation and non-purulent conjunctivitis with edema of the hands and feet. He has been up to date with his immunization. Tongue findings are shown in the image. Which of the following is not likely to occur in the child?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Thrombocytosis is a characteristic finding in Kawasaki disease and commonly occurs in the second week. 

Important laboratory findings of Kawasaki disease are anemia, elevated ESR, and CRP. Major complications of Kawasaki disease are arteritis and aneurysms of coronary vessels, myocarditis, myocardial infarction, and pericarditis.

Patients with coronary artery aneurysms should be treated with low-dose aspirin & who develop coronary thrombosis should be started with fibrinolytic therapy. Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis

questions.text: Nisha presents to the clinic with clinical features suggestive of Kawasaki disease. She was admitted to the ward for treatment. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this disease?
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice in Kawaski disease is IV immunoglobulins. IV immunoglobulins along with aspirin have proven beneficial in preventing coronary artery abnormalities.

questions.text: Who among  the following children with Kawasaki’s disease is at greatest risk for coronary aneurysms?

choices.text: 8 year-old girl with 6 days of high fever and strawberry tongue
5-year-old boy with 8 days of fever and CSF pleocytosis
2-year-old girl with IVIG treatment at 7th day of fever
11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV

questions.solution:
An 11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV is at the greatest risk for coronary aneurysms.

Risk factors for coronary aneurysms in Kawasaki's disease:

  • Age younger than 1 year or older than 9 years
  • Male sex
  • Fever ≥14 days
  • Hematocrit(PCV) <35 percent 
  • Serum sodium concentration <135 mEq/L
  • White blood cell count >12,000/mm3
  • Elevated ESR and CRP

Administration of IVIG during the first 10 days of illness reduces the prevalence of coronary aneurysms fivefold.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the clinic complaining about recurrent painful oral ulcers as shown in the picture. He also experiences repeated episodes of eye redness and pain which subsides with medication. On examination, similar ulcers are seen on his genitals. Behçet disease is suspected. Which of the following feature would you not expect to see in this patient?

choices.text: Tender red nodules on the legs

questions.solution:
Behcet disease is not associated with nail fold capillary abnormalities which is typically seen in systemic sclerosis.

Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Other skin findings include erythema nodosa (red tender nodules on legs) and positive pathergy test (Pustular reaction, 24-48 hrs after sterile needle puncture or normal saline injection).

There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. Dural sinus thrombosis is the most common CNS manifestation in children. Pulmonary aneurysms are the most severe feature of pediatric BD.

It is associated with HLA subtype B51. T helper 17(Th17) cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall.
